<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_setattr:
```c
int lfs_setattr(lfs_t *lfs, const char *path,
        uint8_t type, const void *buffer, lfs_size_t size) {
    int err = LFS_LOCK(lfs->cfg);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }
    LFS_TRACE("lfs_setattr(%p, \"%s\", %"PRIu8", %p, %"PRIu32")",
            (void*)lfs, path, type, buffer, size);

    err = lfs_setattr_(lfs, path, type, buffer, size);

    LFS_TRACE("lfs_setattr -> %d", err);
    LFS_UNLOCK(lfs->cfg);
    return err;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function lfs_setattr:
static int lfs_setattr_(lfs_t *lfs, const char *path,
        uint8_t type, const void *buffer, lfs_size_t size) {
    if (size > lfs->attr_max) {
        return LFS_ERR_NOSPC;
    }

    return lfs_commitattr(lfs, path, type, buffer, size);
}
...
static int lfs_commitattr(lfs_t *lfs, const char *path,
        uint8_t type, const void *buffer, lfs_size_t size) {
    lfs_mdir_t cwd;
    lfs_stag_t tag = lfs_dir_find(lfs, &cwd, &path, NULL);
    if (tag < 0) {
        return tag;
    }

    uint16_t id = lfs_tag_id(tag);
    if (id == 0x3ff) {
        // special case for root
        id = 0;
        int err = lfs_dir_fetch(lfs, &cwd, lfs->root);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }
    }

    return lfs_dir_commit(lfs, &cwd, LFS_MKATTRS(
            {LFS_MKTAG(LFS_TYPE_USERATTR + type, id, size), buffer}));
}
...
static int lfs_commitattr(lfs_t *lfs, const char *path,
        uint8_t type, const void *buffer, lfs_size_t size) {
    lfs_mdir_t cwd;
    lfs_stag_t tag = lfs_dir_find(lfs, &cwd, &path, NULL);
    if (tag < 0) {
        return tag;
    }

    uint16_t id = lfs_tag_id(tag);
    if (id == 0x3ff) {
        // special case for root
        id = 0;
        int err = lfs_dir_fetch(lfs, &cwd, lfs->root);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }
    }

    return lfs_dir_commit(lfs, &cwd, LFS_MKATTRS(
            {LFS_MKTAG(LFS_TYPE_USERATTR + type, id, size), buffer}));
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:

```c
int err = LFS_LOCK(lfs->cfg);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The call to LFS_LOCK(lfs->cfg) does not call lfs_setattr (directly or indirectly) in the provided code. LFS_LOCK is a lock operation (macro or function) and there is no evidence it invokes lfs_setattr or any function that eventually calls lfs_setattr. Therefore this fragment does not introduce recursion. (If LFS_LOCK were implemented such that it called lfs_setattr, that would create an indirect recursive call and violate Rule 17.2, but no such implementation is shown.)
